content.title: Aortoenteric Fistula
content.definition: Aortoenteric fistula (AEF) is an abnormal communication between the aorta (or aortic graft) and the gastrointestinal tract, most commonly the duodenum, presenting with GI bleeding that can be massive and life-threatening.

anatomy.mechanism: Graft pulsation erodes into bowel, or infection weakens tissues

herald_bleed.description: Initial self-limited GI bleed preceding massive hemorrhage
herald_bleed.significance: Critical warning sign - window for diagnosis and treatment
herald_bleed.timing: Hours to weeks before massive bleed

clinical_presentation.massive_hemorrhage: Sudden hematemesis or melena with hemodynamic collapse

diagnosis.high_index_of_suspicion: Any GI bleed in patient with prior aortic surgery

findings: Loss of fat plane between graft and bowel

endoscopy.role: May see erosion or graft material, often only clot/erosion
endoscopy.must_reach: Third/fourth duodenum (often missed with standard EGD)

diagnosis.angiography: May not show fistula, but can demonstrate bleeding

graft_excision_extra_anatomic.approach: Remove graft, repair bowel, axillofemoral bypass
graft_excision_extra_anatomic.timing: Axfem before or after aortic repair

endovascular.role: Bridge to definitive surgery, temporizing in unstable patient
endovascular.limitation: Does not address infection or bowel injury

treatment.bowel_repair: Primary repair, resection, or drainage depending on contamination

learning_objectives: Distinguish primary from secondary aortoenteric fistula
Recognize herald bleed as critical warning sign
Describe diagnostic workup for suspected AEF
clinical_pearls: Any GI bleed in a patient with prior aortic surgery is AEF until proven otherwise
Herald bleed precedes massive hemorrhage - use this window for diagnosis
Third/fourth duodenum is most common location - may be missed on standard EGD
Aortic stump blowout is major risk after graft excision
